subject: Re: [junit] Re: Re: Ant could not create task : junit
msgSnippet: ... That s what we re here for! You shouldn t need the junit.jar and ant-junit.jar explicitly on the classpath like that - the fact that the junit task is
messageBody:
On 4/27/05, Clark I Anderson <anderci@...> wrote:
> Thank you! Success:
>
> 1) I copied junit.jar to ANT_HOME/lib
> 2) I simplified the junit (init-test) task:
> <target name="unit-test" depends="test-var">
> <junit printsummary="true" haltonfailure="true" >
> <classpath>
> <pathelement
> location="${JUNIT_HOME}/junit.jar" />
> <pathelement location="${ANT_HOME}/lib/ant-junit.jar" />
> <pathelement path="build/classes" />
> <pathelement path="test/classes" />
> </classpath>
> <batchtest fork="yes" >
> <formatter type="plain" usefile="false" />
> <fileset dir="test/classes">
> <include name="AllTests.class" />
> <include name="SimpleFractionTest.class" />
> </fileset>
> </batchtest>
> </junit>
> <echo>junit-run complete!</echo>
> </target>
>
> Those two steps let ANT run from the command line.
>
> Several more steps let ANT run from within Eclipse.
>
> Again, thank you.
>
> Clark Anderson
>
That's what we're here for! You shouldn't need the junit.jar and
ant-junit.jar explicitly on the classpath like that - the fact that
the junit task is recognised means that it's already on ANT's
classpath.
